byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Michael R. Gordon from Erbil, Iraq; Omar Al-Jawoshy from Baghdad; Palko Karasz from London; and Mark Mazzetti from Washington.

abstract: Ahmad Chalabi, Iraqi politician who helped convince United States to invade Iraq in 2003 while in exile and who later attempted to return to power there as country disintegrated, dies at age 71; while most associated with Pres George W Bush's decision to invade, Chalabi's relationship with United States stretched over decades.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Chalabi is perhaps the Iraqi most associated with President George W. Bush’s decision to invade the country and topple its longtime dictator, Saddam Hussein.

headline.main: Ahmad Chalabi, Iraqi Politician Who Pushed for U.S. Invasion, Dies at 71
headline.print_headline: Ahmad Chalabi, Force Behind Push for U.S. Invasion of Iraq, Dies at 71

snippet: Mr. Chalabi is perhaps the Iraqi most associated with President George W. Bush’s decision to invade the country and topple its longtime dictator, Saddam Hussein.
